title: Student wore ‘Hitler wanted my kind alive’ T-shirt
text:
The anti-Semitic message was handwritten on a student’s back during a ‘white T-shirt social’ (Picture: Facebook)

An investigation has been launched after a student was seen wearing the racist message ‘Hitler wanted my kind alive’ during a university bar crawl.

The University of Leicester student was taking part in a ‘white T-shirt social’ which involves people scrawling messages onto blank tops.

They have been heavily criticised in the past for allowing people to write offensive, homophobic, sexist or racist comments on each other.

In 2017, Cardiff University banned the social events after pro-rape messages were written alongside Holocaust slogans and phrases including: ‘Don’t speak to me if you’re not white.’

Last week, a picture was posted to Snapchat of the Leicester student wearing the Hitler phrase.

Another student who saw the image said it ‘demonstrates a clear pattern’.

Another Leicester student with an ‘I’m a Nazi’ message (Picture: Facebook)

She wrote on Facebook to say the picture was sent to the university’s Jewish Society as well as a picture of another student wearing a high-vis jacket with the message ‘I am a Nazi’.

Advertisement

Advertisement

That picture was taken inside a McDonalds in Leicester after a student night out last month.

She said: ‘We’ve seen how white T-shirt socials at Exeter, Cardiff, Newcastle and other universities all made national news for anti-semitism and general bigotry.

‘Each of these socials ended up with anti-Semitic slurs and horrific Holocaust-related content. Now, sadly, it looks like Leicester is following suit.’

University of Leicester’s students’ union said the messages displayed were ‘wholly unacceptable’.

In a statement, it said: ‘Offensive behaviour that marginalises any group within our community constitutes a breach of the regulations governing student discipline and we have launched an inquiry into this incident through a disciplinary process.

‘The students’ union requires all those associated with the students’ union to respect the diverse lived experiences in our community.

The picture was sent to the university’s Jewish Society (Picture: Facebook)

‘It is not acceptable to act in an offensive, inflammatory or discriminatory way and we continue to develop extensive training, support and guidance available to clubs, societies and associations on our values and expected behaviour.

‘The entire executive team would like to sincerely apologise for the incident and take accountability for this students’ behaviour.

‘We will ensure we tackle any anti-Semitism and make it wholly clear that white T-shirt socials are not allowable by the union.’

The Campaign Against Anti-Semitism is said to be monitoring the situation.
